div.p: Santa Ana Regional Transportation Center is a passenger rail station and transportation center that serves commuters in the region. Amtrak’s Pacific Surfliner, Metrolink’s Orange County Line and Inland Empire-Orange County Line trains utilize the tracks as part of their daily routes. The station was designed in a Spanish Colonial Revival style that complements much of the region’s buildings from the earlier Spanish era (Great American Stations).The external walls have a stucco finish, the roofs are laid in red Spanish tile, and a light brown stone is used for the trim. In all, the building’s façade retains a mission appearance. Spanish and Mission Revival architecture became quite popular in southern California in the late 19th century. Los Angeles boosters promoted the revitalization movement as a way to connect to the state’s Spanish past, which was romanticized in order to attract settlers from other parts of the country to relocate and to create a regional character (Deverell 142).

note.p: The train station with a Spanish Colonial style is a central transportation hub that commuters utilize on daily bases.
